summary: In this episode Ricky and Steve re-introduce Karl with a Q&A. They discuss some interesting stories Karl has found on the internet and Karl debut's his new music quiz with the working title "What is karl thinking of?". This quiz was a sort of proto-rockbusters that was more difficult and more confusing that Rockbusters would become. The end of the show has some talk of Ricky's boxing match.

transcript.content: Oasis - Little By Little
Back to form there - Oasis and Little By Little. This is Xfm 104.9, I'm Ricky Gervais, who are you?
Er, my name's Steve Merchant, good to see you.
Thanks. Er, with us, er, the producer in the studio is Karl Pilkington. And he'll be doing the m-buttons...
Yeah? You made a good effort there...
Ricky laughs
But er, once again...
Got bored.
Words are your enemy Rick, and they defeated you once again.
Ricky laughs
Just ran out of steam with the sentences.
Ohh, every week I think right, I'm really gonna make an effort now.
Yeah.
I'm gonna, I've, I've chosen some records...
Yeah.
That's it.
That's it. That's as far as it goes isn't it?
Yeah.
Maybe you should write out what you're gonna say at the top of the show?
Ricky laughs
Write that out. Get a nice big crayon.
No, I like to keep a little bit of...
Ricky clicks his fingers
You know.
Little bit of sumin'. Little bit of spark. Little bit of liveliness to it, sure.
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
Sure, sure, sure, sure.
Yeah.
How are you? Good, good to see you
Yeah, great. It's great to be er...
It's great to be out
Ricky laughs
Out of the house again.

Yeah. Oh, yeah. Just, erm, I was going to say because we've been doing this for a long time now with a little break, erm, but XFM are bringing new listeners all the time. I've heard four or five a week.
Really?
Yeah.
Wow, man alive.
New listeners tune in to XFM 104.9.
Radio 1 beware!
Ricky laughs
Yeah, yeah. And, uh, we might take it for granted that people that know who we are, know who you are, know who Karl is.
Sure.
Um.
Old listeners, certainly.
Now, if, if, if you, you know, if you're a regular then you know exactly who we are. But, erm, for those of you who don't, uh, I'll say I'm, I'm Ricky Gervais.
Ricky Gervais, BAFTA-award winning actor and, uh--
Yeah, yeah.
And writer.
Steve Merchant, erm, all those.
Friend of yours.
Yeah, yeah. And, this is the important thing, Karl Pilkington.
Absolutely.

Our, erm, produ-- I say producer. He was the bloke who was lumbered with the job. When I said, "Listen--" See I used to run the desk in the old days when I was working for XFM, I used to press the buttons and run the desk and everything. And then I said, "Listen, I've been on the telly, I do not press my own buttons." And Karl said, "Well, I don't really work weekends." And they went, "Well, you do if you want to keep your job."
Absolutely.
And we were lumbered with him. And then we discovered that he's not just a, a little, like a little dork. A little Manc-y, sort of, idiot.
Sure. Sure.
He's got, he's got a nice shirt. He's got, you know what I mean? He's got something else.
Absolutely. He brings another dimension, yeah.
Yeah. And, uh, he, he started having a little chat and we discovered--
We both love him.
That he had quite a lot to say.

Mm. Well I, I think you're absolutely right and I think, um- I was wondering maybe we should maybe play another tune. But after that, I just think we should refamiliarize our radio audience with Karl.
Yeah.
And any new listeners, just get- let, somehow, kind of let them get to know the real Karl again.
Well if you are new, you'll, you'll find that we like some old songs, some new songs, some chitter-chat. Uh, we get serious sometimes.
Oh yeah.
There's some tears and some laughter.
Yeah.
We kicked off with Oasis's new one, "Little by Little". We're going to go back in time now to Iggy Pop and his Stooges with "I'm Bored."
Iggy Pop - I'm Bored
Iggy Pop, "I'm Bored" on XFM 104.9. I'm Ricky Gervais.
Steve Merchant here.
Yeah. Little Karl Pilkington. Well, to reintroduce or introduce people to the first time to Karl, um, I think we should have a--
Yeah, maybe sort of a, kind of, a quick Q&A Karl, and we don't need, sort of, lengthy answers from you. We don't need lots of detail. Uh, you know, it can be a, just a couple of sentences--
Just to get a flavour of who you are.
To answer these questions. Yeah, so firstly, name obviously Karl Pilkington. Age, Karl?
I'll be, uh, I'll be thirty next month.
Really?
This month. No next, wha- where are we?
Ricky and Steve burst into laughter
I don't think we need to ask any more questions.
I, I don't- I think we've done it.
That's it.
I think we've done it there.
Welcome to the world of Karl Pilkington.
Ricky chuckles
I think- Oh, I thought it would take three or four questions--
I thought it was going to at least--
To really explain what Karl is about.
Yeah, that was, that was the first question.
Ricky and Steve laugh
Oh, oh God!
Absolutely incredible. But um, but we can't really leave it there cause, um--
No.
Because we haven't got enough else to do to fill up the two hours.
No.
So, um, so let's pursue this line of inquiry.
Yeah.
So, um, age? What was the age, Karl? In a couple of--
When were you, when were you born?
I'll be, uh-- '72.
Right, what month, what day?
I'm on the cusp.
Ricky and Steve snigger
You're on the cusp of a day?
Um, twenty-third of September.
Ok.
So anyway-- ok, alright. Good.
And there you were talking there about, um, obviously your star sign, were you, on the cusp?
Yep.
You believe in that, do you?
No.
You don't believe in star signs?
No, not really.
But you do believe in ghosts, I understand.
No, because the star signs--
The paranormal.
Yeah, but the star sign thing, you've got how many, how many different star signs are they?
Twelve, innit?
Right, and then you've got, like, loads of people.
Yeah. You do the math.
So they're saying that, you know, there's only twelve different sorts of people in the world.
Exactly. That's exactly right. It's, it's made-up. It's made-up nonsense. It's non-science.
It's pseudo-science.
It's, yes. It's, it's, it's, it's hairy-man and, um, dyed-hair-woman science.
Yes.
Innit?
Alright?
Yeah.
Anyway, back to you, Karl. Where were you born?
In, uh, in Manchester.
Okay. What GCSE results did you get?
Ricky sniggers
I got, uh, was it an E? Got an E in history.
You got an E in history. And how did you find out that?
You found out.
Cause you thought you, you didn't, you couldn't remember what you got. You didn't turn up and you thought you'd done about three, one of which wasn't history, and actually--
I knew, I knew I did art.
Yeah, you didn't. I'm telling you didn't cause we checked. You did one. You turned up for history, you did history, you got an E in history.
No, I definitely did art. I made a little clay man.
Steve laughs
Yeah, you've got to register for O-levels. You don't just do it and then phone 'em up and say, "How was that?" And they go--
"I'm sending you a clay man."
Ricky laughs
"Send me a grade."
Yeah, yeah. There's all things, there's forms to fill out and things like that, Karl.
Anyway...
Yeah, go on.
Ricky sniggers
Who was your closet childhood friend?
Closest. At what age?
Well, when you were young, when you were--
Oh, I remember this. It's a fella. Um, someone Makin, innit?
There's, there's, well he wasn't really a close mate. Darren Buckley was me--
Darren Buckley?
Yeah.
Tell us briefly about Darren. I'd forgotten about Darren.
He's the one who, um, all the, all the girls liked him.
Did they?
He had, uh, he had permed hair. Used to--
Ricky quietly laughs
Have his hair like a footballer.
Sure.
Um--
Were you jealous of him?
His dad was a copper.
Did you hang around with Darren, like, in the hope of getting of, maybe, his, kind of, castoffs?
Nah. I, I- You see, it's weird with me. I wasn't that bothered about having loads of mates an' that. I sort of--
Sure.
I had lots of mates, but I could do without 'em.
You had a magpie, didn't you?
I was happy, I was happy playing with me magpie.
Yeah, and what happened to him?
It, uh, flew away.
Yeah.
But I wasn't bothered because it was giving me grief towards the end, wasn't it. It was--
Ricky laughs
It was popping me, me Grifter tyres an' that.
Ricky continues to laugh
Yeah, sure.
Flying down, pecking me head.
Sure. Now you went to school with a number or different interesting people. Some of whom are freaks.
Two of which, I understand, had big heads and webbed toes.
Is that right?
Yet they were not related to each other and they weren't friends with each other. Why weren't they friends with each other?
Because that'd be obvious.
Ricky laughs
Did they, did they wear shoes or did they walk around in their, in their webbed, uh, feet?
Were they good at swimming? Were they good at swimming?
Uh, I don't know. I don't they ever, ever went swimming.
Did they ever talk, did they, did they ever look over at each other and think--
"Yeah, we should hang out more."
Ricky laughs
I told you something in the week, as well, there was another lad at school- had a pigeon chest.
He had a what?
Can we come back to this?
He had a pigeon chest?
I think we should play a record, Karl. Cause we, I think we've hooked them now. I think, I think--
Yeah. There's no one switching off now, Rick.
No, play a record.
Blur - Coffee & TV
Blur, "Coffee & TV." Karl, uh- I said, "It's not the best Blur song" when it was playing, you know, I don't want to diss it, but it's not the best one, I mean, that, that's fact, you know?
Absolutely, sure.
Karl went, "I like the video though. Had a little milk carton."
Yeah.

"Bit sad. It's tragic, innit?" He went, and this is all to himself. I'm not even joining in. And then he went, Yeah, but its alright in the end. He goes, He finds a little girl milk carton. Just lives out a little thing in his- is that like you on your paper round, that little milk carton walking around like that? I imagine youoh, people that dont know about, if you just tuned in Karl had a paper round--
Its his favourite job ever.
And he maintains its the best job hes ever had. Innit, Karl?
Karl starts to talk then sighs
Go on.
I dont know whats so weird about that.
Its a paper round.
Yeah, but look- forget all that.
Its not the most fulfilling of jobs.
Look at, look at the way it works, right. You get it out of the way at the start of the day so you got the rest of the day to yourself.
Ricky quietly laughs
Sure.
Just as the same as signing on.
Your own, youre your own boss, you know?
Same as signing on.
Well youre not your own boss. The guy at the newsagent is your boss.
Ricky laughs
Yeah.
Nahhh...
Ricky and Steve laugh
Thats great.
Youve proven me wrong there, yeah.
Yeah, thats great. Nahhhhh. Yeah, nahhhhh, not really. Would that stand up in court? Well you were found with the dagger. Nahhhhhhhhhh.
Steve laughs
Was I?
When are we, uh, when are we playing me new game?
Oh, Karls got a new game. Karls so excited. Oh, just--
Well we were talking about something before--
Yeah, the freaks he used to go, the people with big heads, two webbed feet, didnt hang around each other, that would be too obvious. Um, you had a fella with a pigeon chest.
Yeah, whats the story with the pigeon chest?
Dont know how it happened. It was like, it looked like somebody sort of hit him on the back with a big hammer and it had come out of the front.
Yeah.
And Ive never seen it since.
Could that have been the answer?
What, why his, why he had it?
Yeah, why he had it. Possibly, I suppose, in your neck of the woods.
Yeah. I dunno, I never asked him.
Its just come back to haunt you, has it, the pigeon chest?

No, its just that, uh, you know, when you, when you mentioned about kids at school I forgot all about him. Youre talking about the kids with the webbed feet and the big heads and I forgot about the little, old--
Pigeon chest.
Pigeon boy.
Well listen are you- Im a big fan of that TV show, its on digital TV, a lot of people wont have it, but Inside the Actors Studio with James Lipton.
Yeah, yeah.
And he interviews lots of big Hollywood stars and he always asks them these same questions at the end. Can I just run a few of em past you?
Go on.
Okay. So, um, if you could do any other profession other than the one you do now, what profession would you do?
Can you just change that to apart from a paper round?
Apart from a paper round?
Ooh
You could do any other profession, Karl.
Erm, and it doesnt matter about, like--
It doesnt matter if youve got the skills or anything, in an ideal world, if you had the ability.
Well, I think Im about to buy somewhere so I reckon something, you know, using, using tools and like doing a bit of plumbing an that.
So a plumber.
Well, sort of an all-rounder.
Right, right.
A handy man.
Well, yeah, yeah. I think, you know, you dont get paid that much, but its useful, innit. So--
You could get your own show, couldnt you, with Carol Smillie eventually?
Well, all that, but the money that you dont make, you save by not having to pay someone else do the chores, do you know what I mean?
Right, okay. I, I dont know what that sentence meant.
Steve hoots
Right, right, look. A plumber, how much, how much is the average plumber on?
The money you dont make, you save on not getting someone else to do it. No, just think of that, no break that sentence down. Is there any--
Sorry, Rick, sorry, but, uh people who live in glass houses.
Ricky laughs
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
Anyway, lets go back to Lipton quickly. Weve got a couple to get through here. So your favorite noise or sound?
Uh
Favorite sound or noise?
Ooh
Is it me?
No.
Its not me?
Er, hang on a minute.
Ricky gets louder
Its not me? Are you sure its not me, Karl?
I like, I like Elvis.
Noise. Who? Elvis?
Elvis. In the Ghetto.
The sound of Elvis.
Elvis, In the Ghetto. Brilliant.
Okay, and your least favorite noise or sound? I dont think it should really be records and music. Noises, things that you hear. At home or whatever.
Uhh Maybe like the sound of a--
Least favorite noise.
Least favorite
Sound of--
Probably, like, uh--
Sound of ghosts?
Fire engines an that.
Right.
Thats, thats annoying.
Ricky laughs
Except if your house was on fire, presumably.
I think its a bit unnecessary.
Ricky and Steve laugh
You think that theyre just doing it to wind people up?
I live on, like, a busy street and its happening all the time and its, it is like just sort of have a blast of it and people will hear it.
Sure.
You dont have to keep it going.
Sure, sure.
So that is, yeah, pretty annoying.
Okay, and, um, if Heaven exists, Karl, when you get to the Pearly gates, what would you like God to say to you as he welcomes you into Heaven? What would you like God to say to you?
Uhhwho asks these? Wha-what shows this?
Its a program where, um, celebrities are interviewed by a guy, an American interviewer, and he always asks these questions at the very end.
What would I say to God?
What would you say to God- If you believed in Heaven and if Heaven exists, when you eventually got to Heaven and youre welcomed in through the gates--
Like Parker, in your stussy t-shirt and your--
Yeah, what do you want God to say to you as he welcomes you in?
Say, uh, You alright? Uh, dunno just be, just be friendly.
Ricky and Steve laugh
The Reindeer Section- Grand Parade
Thats The Reindeer Section.
Beautiful.
Yeah, nice stuff. Um, its a kind of Scottish super-group, lots of different artists--
Belle and Sebastian.
Ricky and Steve talk over each other
Is it the lead singer from em?

It may well be, yeah, on that particular track. Different people, Mull Historical Society, Idlewild, Teenage Fanclub, different people from all those bands get together with a guy called Gary Lightbody from Snow Patrol and he writes the tunes.
And all that on XFM 104.9, Steve.
Ab-solutely. Let me just name that track, that track was Grand Parade from their current album, Son of Evil Reindeer.
Feeder - Come back around.
Feeder, Come Back Around on XFM 104.9. Im Ricky Gervais. Uhh.. but who are you?
Oh, thanks for asking, Rick. Steve Merchant.
With us, Karl Pilkington. Well, Karl, um- Now, I know I shouldnt, but I met Karl in the week again, Steve.
I tell you you shouldnt do this, you know you shouldnt--

I know, but then when he starts, he starts saying things like, I was a (unintelligible), I go, No, no. Save it, save it. And then we just sit there and Im scared to talk in case he comes up- But, um, you did tell me a couple of little things, didnt ya? True stories, that are, I mean I enjoyed it. Can you tell, um, Steve the one about the doctor?
Right--
Oh God. Is this something that happened to a friend of yours, or is this a--
No, no. I read about it.
You read about it, okay.
Umtheres this little lad, right? First of all, its years ago, right?
What, in olden times?
They didnt have, they didnt have decent doctors in, like, every town an that.
Yeah.
And, uh, this little kid, hes dead ill, right.
Yeah.
And the local doctor--
Well, theres a phone call involved so I dont want people to get the impression that its--
Well let me get to it!
Medieval times.

Err yeah, but I didnt say that, I just said its years ago. So this kids ill, right, and hes lying in the bed and hes all, like, all going funny colour an that. And his mom says, Im gonna get the local doctor round. The local doctor comes round and says, Ooh.. Dunno, dunno whats up with him. He said, um, leave it with me--
Ricky and Steve laugh.
Leave it with me.
Leave it with me. What, the doctor said that?
Yeah, he said, Ill, um, Ill phone up a top doctor--
Okay.

Who was in America, or somethin like that. And, uh, so he goes to the phone in his office and he calls America and cause its years ago, the phone line isnt that good, its all crackly an that, alright. So hes talking to the doctor and hes saying, Ive got this kid, hes a funny colour and, uh you know, hes really weak an that.
Hes not giving him much to go on.
So, uh, so the American doctor, right? He goes, Yeah, what you want to do- and its all breaking up, right? He goes, What youve got to do, youve got to--
Karl mimics a phone call breaking up
Its all breaking up. Youve got to give him some, uh parrots blood. Right?
Some parrots blood?
Well, thats what he thought he said. But the line was really bad, he meant parents blood, but he heard that he said parrots blood.
Oh God.
He said, Okay, Ill do that. Leave it to me.
I can see where this is going.
He goes, goes to, uh, a pet shop. Said, Give us, like, half a dozen parrots.
Sure.
Takes em around to the kids house. Takes the blood from the parrots, puts it in the kid, kids fine.
The kids fine?
It worked.
Ricky laughs
Ive never heard such a load of shite in my life.
Steve laughs
I never heard such twaddle, such, just made up enhanced, exaggeratedbollocks in my life.
What a load of old rubbish, Karl.
I mean, when he told me this, he said the doctor said, Well what do I do? And the doctor on the other end said, Give him some blood. And the doctor went, Where do I get blood from?
Ricky and Steve laugh
So, hang on--
Where do I get blood from? Get him some parents blood. Give him some parents blood! Give him some parents, some parents blood! Yeah
Ricky and Steve laugh
But hang on, I just need to know where you read this--
Sorry, Karl, Ive stitched you up. You know when he said, he said, So do you believe that? I went, Tell it to Steve. He went, Do you believe it? I went, Tell it to Steve! Karl
That, that was on the internet. About illnesses.
Where is it on the internet? What, what webpage?
I was looking at stuff, I was looking at stuff this morning cause of, um, Uri Geller last night.
Ricky laughs
Eating all that funny food an that and also, uh- They all got a bit scared last night, didnt they, with the snake.
I didnt see it last night. Is this Im a CelebrityGet Me Out of Here!?
Yeah, yeah. Got all worried about a snake getting on the, uh, sort of wanderin about in between the sleeping bags an stuff. And, um, they were all scared and--
Leave it with me! Sorry, the doctor says, Leave it with me.
Leave it with me.
Ricky laughs
Yeah, ahh... leave it with me.
Well, they were all scared cause theres a snake and its so easy to find stuff out. Before they, before they- where are they? Where is this jungle?
Australia, I think.
Before they went, give it half an hour on the internet, I found out with snakes you dont need to worry, right? Um, theyre deaf, they dont got any ears, so as long as youre really quiet--
Creep around.
Theyll probably leave you alone. And also they dont have eyelids.
Uh-huh.
Erm, so they were suggesting, if ones coming towards you, just, like, kick sand in its eyes.
Ricky quietly laughs
Cause it cant blink and it leaves it a bit, like, annoyed.
Yeah.
And it wanders off. But they didnt do any research before they went.
Yeah.

That- your, your- I think your knowledge was probably in good stead. I dont think you need to know any more than you know. Um, well were going to come back to that because he also explained to me where, uh, a saying comes from that I want you to be part of. But, uh--
Oh, and also we should mention as well, Karl youve come up with a competition, is this right?
Brilliant competition.
He thinks this can go to television.
Is this an idea youve come up with?
Yeah.
Karl, Im so looking forward to it.

So am, I mean, Im looking forward to it. Um, continuing, uh, our exposure of myths and legends, apocryphal tale, we exposed that myth that some maybe older rockers have had it and theyve got, they were never any good and the kids today--
Oh, I dont want to hear that.
People like Rod Stewart--
Rod Stewart is a great artist. Hes a slightly laughable man, but a great artist.
Lets got back to when it was, when he was rocking.
When he cut the mustard?
Yeah!
Rod Stewart- You Wear It Well
Rod Stewart, You Wear It Well.
Great tune.

On XFM 104.9. Yeah, this doctor, I mean, we should find out who he is, really, and if hes still practicing cause it, it worries me a little bit. That he, you know, did that. Also, I mean, he thinks he got away with it, but how could he be sure those parrots wouldnt talk?
True, true.
Do you know what I mean? There were six of them. They probably got together, and, they prob- they probably put it on the internet.
I mean, I feel that that story, Karl, it asks more questions than it answers, really.
Ricky laughs
Yeah, like most of your stories, to be honest.
Yeah, thats the problem. I always feel them- I always feel like I need a little more information, like did the parrot boy continue to live?
Yeah.
You know, to a ripe old age or did he die weeks later after this charlatan doctor who was going around, you know--
Did he break his nose trying to crack a big nut?
No, I think, I think hes, uh, he was alright. He, he lived to a--
See, Id have shou- If I was that doctor, I would have shouted that down the phone, Are you sure you said parrots blood?
Yeah.
Are you sure it was parrots blood?
Listen, I-I mean, you know, Im not the best doctor in the world, but did you say parrots blood?
Steve chuckles
Yeah, but what youre forgetting is youre going back to the time where, like, they used leeches to do, like--
No, no were not!
Were going back to the late 70s, if theres a phone call to America direct.
Cmon Karl, they werent calling America, like, in the medieval times or-or in the Victorian age. Karl, think about it, Karl.
(quietly): Yeah.
You know, this has got to be, like, the, like, you know,30s or 40s at the earliest. You know?
Ricky giggles
Alright.
Im intrigued to know where this- I think theres someone on web whos just putting information on there to lead you astray.
Yeah.
Cause youre the only person who finds this stuff. Other people are using this to write theses
Why were you, why were you looking at that then? What were you
I always look at weird stuff.
What were you looking for?
But what do you type in the search engine to find parrot blood stories?
What were you looking for? Wha--
There was this woman with a weird head.
Ricky laughs
Why were you looking for that? What were you--
Just cause Id heard about it, Id heard, like, someone talking about it on another station, right.
Right.
About this woman with a, with a funny head.

Right, I love the fact, I love the fact youre intrigued with these things. You go into the basement of Waterstones or Dillions or somewhere and theres these, theres these medical books that youll love em, mate.
Yeah, but this is free on the internet, innit? Its all there.
Yeah.
So what did you- you typed in weird head woman or
Ricky sings "Lady with head..."
Weir-weird, weird people, or something I put in.
Sure.
Yeah, did you come up?
Ricky and Steve laugh
Seven thousand hits, Karl Pilkington.
Ricky laughs
But its all there, innit. Its interesting, the one that I was telling you before about, um, the whats-her-name, the lost letter.
The lost letter. Whats this?

The lost, the lost postcard thats, uh, just turned up. Some woman sent a postcard years and years ago to her niece or something and her niece was, like, three years old back then. And just now, like, I think, like, yesterday or the day before it turned up, the postcard turned up seventy-four years late.
Seventy-four years late?
It took seventy-four years.
And that three year old girl has been living in the same house that whole time.
Well, yeah.
Ricky laughs
Theres nowt weird about that.
You see what we mean when theres always a question you can ask to just scratch the credibility of these stories. Theres always- its like the apocryphal tale--
Was this the slugs? Was this those slugs from last week? That were stealing--

Yeah. Cause the postman slug is useless. Its round takes him seventy four years. And then hes got to go back to the beginning and hes got seventy four ye- and he cant carry the bag. Thats when they go, thats when they turn to glue, thats why they turn to glue.
Ohh Its pitiful.
It is pitiful.
So you dont believe that someone sent a postcard years ago and somehow its been stuck in the bottom of a postbag or something and its only just got--
Stuck in the bottom of a postbag? That means that theres, like, a ninety-five year old postman whos still wandering around!
Yeah, did, did she, did she have to pay, like, the, the difference on the charges?
Uh
Cause presumably--
It wouldnt have had Queen Elizabeths, uh--
It was a penny black, presumably, was it?
Yeah. What would be on the stamp? It would have been invalid, surely.
Ricky laughs
I dunno.
See these are the questions you should ask yourself.
No, no, no, no, no.
Go on.
Cause if its the postmans fault, the postman cant--
The postman--
Hes dead!
Who was eighty-three at the time, himself, wasnt he.
No, he is dead. Yeah, hell be well and truly dead now.
Yeah.
But the fact is that the post office made an error--
Ricky chuckles
Right, they lost his letter.
Sure.
Its only just turned up. They cant turn around and say, Sorry about this. I hope it isnt urgent.
Ricky laughs
Its turned up seventy-four years late and by the way, you owe us twenty-five pence. They wouldnt do that.

Phone in if you want to hear some classic rock.
Classic rock, indeed.
Oh, we ripped off Mayo, lets do Vance.
Steve laughs
Absolutely. Lets just steal ideas from other, better DJs.
Okay.
Um--
Oh, wha-what could we have?
Oh, theres some great ideas out there, Im sure.
I-I mean, if you, if you wanted, like, any Fix It is done. If you, maybe, wanted to eat a pack lunch on a rollercoaster.
On a rollercoaster, yeah, with some Boy Scouts.
Or-or-or dance with Bananarama.
Yeah.
Then, then were--
Or Five Star.
Ricky laughs
Yeah.
I love the fact that Five Star have reformed; theres three of em.
Ricky laughs
Have you heard about this?
No.
The Streets - Weak Becomes Heroes

metadata.song_track: Dead Leaves and the Dirty Ground

transcript.content: The White Stripes- Dead Leaves and the Dirty Ground
White Stripes, on XFM 104.9. Im Ricky Gervais, with me Steve Merchant--
Hello.
Karl Pilkington. Well, I had a good time.
Ive enjoyed it. Yeah, its been nice. Good fun.
Some good tracks, some, some laughs, some new, uh, competition by Simon Mayo.
Steve laughs
Absolutely.
That was, that was great.
Yeah, yeah. Karl, have you heard, um, the big news? That, uh, Ricky Gervais is, uh, looking to take up, um- well, you explain it, Gervais, cause Im not, Im not--
No, its not big news.
No--
What are you talk- what do you mean?
You-you-you-youre taking up boxing, in this right?
N-no.
What is the story? You want to be fighting for money?
No! Yeah, bare-knuckle fighting.
No, cmon. What is it?
No, all it is, Ive been watching this, um, show on cable called Born to Fight and its on sort of late--
Steve laughs
On later when you flick around and I think its on after Roadies, which is like--
Roadies?

Yeah, its a bloke, one bloke with a camera who goes on tour with different people. He went with Motorhead, he went with the Meatloaf, um, uh, uh, Tribute Act. He went on with Coldplay was in one of them. Its this, sort of, cheap, sort of--
Is this when all the other channels have been switched off, this is the only one left?

Yeah, yeah. Yeah, exactly, yeah. And theres one called Born to Fight and, uh, they just take a different story. It might be an amateur fight or it might be an unlicensed fight, not illegal. Um, or it might be white-collar, which is what Im thinking of doing.
Wha-whats white-collar?
White-collar is just people who want to fight and, uh, its organized--
Is it like Fight Club?

Yes, but its charity, its-its safe. Its-its a charity do. Youll have big events and its just two people that, you know, arent boxers, arent amateur boxers and they get in the ring and do three, three, um, two-minute rounds and they just lay into each other. They got headguards on and, uh--
Rick, I dont mean to alarm you, but, um, you know, we work together, obviously, and we make The Office and stuff. Your face is my fortune.
Ricky laughs
Rick, I cant have you--
It must be a bit of a worry for you.
It is. Im not going- well, your heart is, as well, is also a concern.
Yeah.
And your eating and stuff.
Well, when I say--
No, no, no, wait a minute--
But when I said I was going to get fit, you were going, No, Gervais. Youre only funny cause youre fat.
No, I agree, this is true. But Im saying theres a difference between being fit--
Yeah.
And, um, I would say for instance, dont eat--
Getting your face smashed in.
Well, dont eat, dont eat, kind of, you know, cheese and bacon, you know, on their own.
All day.
All day or for breakfast. So what Im saying is theres a difference between, you know, exercising and then having your face beaten in and what Im saying is that you- I just dont think its a good idea.
But I might win.
No, the prob- what I dont- you- thats-thats-thats irrelevant. Youre still going to take a couple blows to the face and the point is this, Rick, youre not going to win.
Why?
No, because you are delusional. You think that you are probably the worlds greatest boxer.
Ricky laughs
Ever since Ive known you, youve seemed to think thats the case cause youve watched all the Rocky films--
Ricky continues to laugh
And you think, Thats fair enough. That seems straightforward enough. But look at your physique. Yeah, youve got some upper body strength--
Yeah.
But, you know, youve also got some up- some lower belly strength, as well, Ive noticed.
Ricky laughs
And, um, and my concern is youre going to go in there and youre not only going to be a broken man when you realize that youre just not as handy in the ring as you thought you were--
Yeah.
But also, youre going to, youre going to incur some injuries.
This is fighting talk. This is fighting talk.
The first rule of Fight Club is dont talk about Fight Club.
This makes me want to do it more now, just cause of you. It was the same when Adrian didnt agree that Rocky could beat--
Right.
Clubber Lang.
Yeah, yeah.
Oh, she-she made that mistake. Then she made the same mistake with Draco!
At what age, Rick, at what age--
Then she turns up at the end to take the credit, didnt she?

When you were this, kind of, thin, nimble youth in your makeup and eyeliner and all the rest of it, you- I bet you had no id- you had no thoughts about boxing. It never came into your mind, did it? So at what age did you suddenly think, Wait a minute, Ive taken the wrong path in life. I couldve been the worlds heavyweight.
I dont, I dont think I could.
When have you, when have you suddenly decided that you can, you-you can suddenly be a bit street tough? I dont understand why this has suddenly come about in later life.
Well, Im not putting out a shout, am I, to fight people. Its not- Im not- its not like Im Noel Gallegher and Robbie Williams.
But youve got to find somebody else to, presumably, fight with.
Yeah, but itll probably be a business man who wants to fight.
Right. You know theres something really weird about that. Dont you think that soun- have you just listened to yourself, I want to fight another- I want to fight a businessman!
Ricky laughs
Please may I fight a businessman?
No, I dont want to fight a businessman!
You just said!
I want to fight someone who wants to- you know, its not--
I want to fight them now!
Ricky laughs
I want to fight somebody.
Say it like that, it sounds a bit mad, yeah.
Bring em on, I want to fight people.

No, but its more- its more the effort and the training, the equipment to it, like climbing a mountain. I mean, I think climbing a mountain and doing a marathon is ridiculously macho. Its not the fact that you can do it--
No, thats not macho compared with boxing.

Well, it is macho, isnt it? Theres no reason to climb a mountain, theres no reason to do a marathon. If you can run a mile, thats all you need. The fact that you train, is whether you can do it yourself and achieve something and this is more, like, the training and the learning a skill and seeing if it works. I-I dont want to get in there--
But arent you concerned that you might get beaten? Or you might get beaten up, I should say.
No! Whats the worst that could happen?
Youll get black eyes, bruises and--
Well, bruises, bruises heal.
Gervais, let me just remind you--
What?
Of the time we were working in your flat, right?
Ricky giggles
And you immediately- I think, I dont know, to this day, what happened, but you started choking, you clasped your chest--
Ricky laughs
You were breathing, wheezing, right? I leapt over to you. I remember screaming, I dont know the Heimlich maneuver.
Yeah.
If youve swallowed something, I cant help.
Yeah.
You gained your breath, you gained your composure. I said, What happened? Did you eat something, did it go down the wrong way? You said, No, I swallowed some dust.
Ricky laughs
I swallowed some dust. You breathed some dust in that was in the air, there was some dust in the air, you breathed that in; it knocked you out for two days.
Ricky howls with laughter
Rick, you were in bed for two days.
Yeah. I love that.
I dont think, I dont think youre the man for the job.
I had some dust. What do you think this businessmans going to do to you? Hurt ya permanent!
Yeah!
Hell hurt ya permanent!
You found a lump, didnt you, on your testicle once. We sat in a doctors waiting room, I remember, for about forty-five minutes.
It all checked out, it was fine. I think I went twice, didnt I? I said to the doctor at one point, I said, Did you check round the back?
Yeah.
I was thinking he hadnt checked it. Yeah. Oh, dear.
Yeah, just because he hadnt found anything. My point is this--
Ohh
Youre something of a hypochondriac.
Ricky laughs
You know youre something of a hypochondriac. You know that already. So why do you think this is going to be any different?
Well--
If you take, when you take a first blow to the head, youll take the punch, youll immediately think youve got some kind of, you know, brain disorder and--
No, Ive always--
And youll be done for. And you'll give up. You'll throw in the towel.
Ive always wanted to do it, but I just thought- I just wanted to make sure, I wanted to know that I definitely lost my looks.
Right.
And, um, Ive seen some of the publicity shots, Ive got mirrors in my house, so now- Ive definitely lost my looks now, Ive got nothing to lose.
Yeah.
So I want, you know, maybe a younger, more handsome man. I want to teach him a lesson.
Rick, Ill end with this.
What?
For people who listen to this show regularly, you already sound like youre punch drunk.
Ricky laughs
Alright? And thats just your natural way of talking. Please, lets not do the real thing.
Oh, play a record. Ohh
I mean, is it going to be televised?
Oh, it- well, we could get it on DVD, maybe well release it.
Okay, now Im interested.
Ricky laughs
Okay.
Is there money to be made?
Yeah, lots of money.
Alright, maybe we should talk about it.
Okay.

metadata.song_track: Hate To Say I Told You So

transcript.content: The Hives: Hate to Say I Told You So
Hives, on XFM 104.9.
And joining us now live at Shaquille Peoples Home where, uh, TV star Ricky Gervais is taking on his first, uh, non-professional bout. Um, Ricky, who are you fighting this evening?
Uh, bloke called Pete Smedley.
Okay, Pete Smedley. How olds Pete?
Hes seventy-two.
Seventy-two years old.
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
And, uh, youre very excited about the fight, Ive noticed.
Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah.
Now, Petes just recovered from a massive coronary, hasnt he?
Well, I dont want to get into that. Hes deemed himself fit and thats-thats good enough for me.
Steve laughs
If he, if he wants to fight- listen, right. Someone just called up and said, uh, theyll fight me. He sounded--
This is such a bad idea.

Pretty, pretty tasty. I said, How tall are you? He said, Five foot, eleven. I said, What do you weigh? He said, 13 stone. I said, How old are you? Twenty-seven. I explained to him Im looking for someone a lot older and smaller.
Steve laughs
Absolutely.
Lot, lot older and smaller than that.
Don Estelle.
Ricky laughs
If Don Estelle from, uh- what was it?
Im going to show you now, Steve. This is just a sport, you know. People go, Oh, dont go into badminton. The shuttlecock will hurt your eye! Its just a sport.
Okay, fair enough. Im sure well resume this conversation next week. And, of course, well also be playing more of, uh, Karls new brilliant game. With prizes, hopefully.
Yeah, yeah. Simon Mayos What is Karl Thinking?
Steve laughs

Absolutely. And, um, well leave you with a song for, uh, the ladies, Rick, if I may. This is by- my friend Harry, you may know, sends me tracks, every so often, I should listen to and this is a particular favourite of mine. Pretty Please, and its by Kevin Tihistas Red Terror. I dont know if Ive pronounced that right, but enjoy that and well see you next week.
Lets get ready to rumble.
Steve laughs
Kevin Tihistas Red Terror- Pretty Please

synopsis.description: Ricky introduces the show for any new listeners.
Re-introduction of Karl Q&A: How old is karl?
Q&A: What GCSE results did Karl get?
Q&A: Who was Karl's closes childhood friend?
How to fight off a snake.
Origin of the phrase "chucking the baby out with the bath water".
Karl introduces his idea for a music-based competition (proto-rockbusters).

trivia.description: This section is missing from the audio.
This is somehow not completely made up by karl: https://www.thevintagenews.com/2018/08/09/parrots-blood/
This section is missing from the audio.
